answers.answer: This is a HIV risk assestment forum.

Would you approach the question from a risk assessment perspective if I add the following:Assume a person has multiple high risk unprotected sexual exposures but has not yet performed any HIV testing over several years.  If they finally went for testing 6 months after the last exposure, and showed a negative result, would there still be chance for a LTNP to "hide" antibodies which led to the negative result?  Or do LTNP show antibodies like everyone else?
Testing 3 months post exposure would be conclusive.
Ok, so it sounds like LTNP are the same as the next guy when it comes to developing and showing antibodies.  Thanks for the info!
LTNP and Elite controllers test positive in the same window period as everyone else. Antibodies have nothing to do with a LTNP or Elite controller, it's the viral load.

Last question from me before I check out the Diabetes forums....After showing positive on antibody tests, can LTNPs and ECs fly under the radar of PCR tests?  I suspect this is why PCRs are not approved as diagnostic measures for HIV, but I'm only guessing.Thanks everyone.
If the PCR RNA was used for a VL test it may say it's undetectable but that is what everyone that is HIV positive wants to see.

question: Pretty cool and resourceful forum here.Question about Long term non progressors and/or elite controllers:Do they have a longer window period to identify antibodies?  Or do they typically develop antibodies around the same time, and they are just able to "manage" the virus without medication longer?
title: Long term non progressors
